natural problem: 3 cards are chosen at random from a standard 52-card deck.  What is the probability that they can be arranged into a group of three consecutive cards, all of the same suit? For this problem, an Ace can either come before a 2 or after a King, but not both (so A23 and QKA both count, but KA2 doesn't).
natural solution: There are $\binom{52}{3} = 22,\!100$ ways to choose 3 cards out of 52, without regard to order. For any suit, there are 12 possible triples of consecutive cards (since the three consecutive cards can start on an A, 2, 3, ..., or Q, but not on a K).

Since there are 4 suits, there are $4\cdot12=48$ valid triples. The chance that three cards chosen randomly are three consecutive cards of the same suit is therefore $\frac{48}{22,\!100}=\boxed{\frac{12}{5,\!525}}$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = 12 / 5525"
shows  "P = (\<Sum>suit \<in> {1..4}. \<Sum>start \<in> {1..10}. 1) / (\<Sum>card1 \<in> {1..52}. \<Sum>card2 \<in> {1..51}. \<Sum>card3 \<in> {1..50}. 1)"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 3 cards are chosen at random from a standard 52-card deck.  What is the probability that they can be arranged into a group of three consecutive cards, all of the same suit? For this problem, an Ace can either come before a 2 or after a King, but not both (so A23 and QKA both count, but KA2 doesn't). The final Answer is \frac{12}{5,\!525}
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{52}{3} = 22,\!100$ ways to choose 3 cards out of 52, without regard to order. For any suit, there are 12 possible triples of consecutive cards (since the three consecutive cards can start on an A, 2, 3, ..., or Q, but not on a K).
 Since there are 4 suits, there are $4\cdot12=48$ valid triples. The chance that three cards chosen randomly are three consecutive cards of the same suit is therefore $\frac{48}{22,\!100}=\boxed{\frac{12}{5,\!525}}$
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = 12 / 5525"
shows  "P = (\<Sum>suit \<in> {1..4}. \<Sum>start \<in> {1..10}. 1) / (\<Sum>card1 \<in> {1..52}. \<Sum>card2 \<in> {1..51}. \<Sum>card3 \<in> {1..50}. 1)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: What is the probability of drawing a sequence of 3 cards from a standard deck of 52 cards such that each card is of the same suit and their values are in increasing order (assuming Aces are low)? The final answer is $\frac{12}{5525}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda> x. x * 3 * 4 / (52 * 51 * 50))"
shows  "probability 12 = 12 / 5525"
a_1.formal solution:

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda> x. x * 3 * 4 / (52 * 51 * 50))"
shows  "probability 12 = 12 / 5525"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Calculate the probability of an event that occurs 12 times given that it has a probability of $x = \frac{3 \times 4}{52 \times 51 \times 50}$ for each occurrence. The final answer is $\frac{12}{5525}$.

a_2.formal problem:

shows  "three_cards_probability = 12 / 5525"

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob :: real
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<lambda> (success_cases, total_cases). real success_cases / real total_cases)"
and h1 : "success_cases = 12"
and h2 : "total_cases = 5525"
shows  "prob (success_cases, total_cases) = 12 / 5525"

fixes prob :: real

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob :: "real"
assumes h0 : "prob = 12 / 5525"
shows  "prob = (\<Sum>suit \<in> {Clubs, Diamonds, Hearts, Spades}. \<Sum>start \<in> {2..10}. (1/13) * (1/51) * (1/50))"
note: In the Isabelle version, Clubs, Diamonds, Hearts, and Spades represent the four suits in a standard deck of cards.
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 3 cards are chosen at random from a standard 52-card deck.  What is the probability that they can be arranged into a group of three consecutive cards, all of the same suit? For this problem, an Ace can either come before a 2 or after a King, but not both (so A23 and QKA both count, but KA2 doesn't). The final Answer is \frac{12}{5,\!525}
 ### Proof

 *)

theorem
fixes prob :: "real"
assumes h0 : "prob = 12 / 5525"
shows  "prob = (\<Sum>suit \<in> {Clubs, Diamonds, Hearts, Spades}. \<Sum>start \<in> {2..10}. (1/13) * (1/51) * (1/50))"
note: In the Isabelle version, Clubs, Diamonds, Hearts, and Spades represent the four suits in a standard deck of cards.
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given that there is a probability of $\frac{12}{5525}$ of a certain event occurring, prove that this probability is equal to the sum of the probabilities of drawing three consecutive cards in increasing order from a standard deck of 52 playing cards, considering all suits (Clubs, Diamonds, Hearts, and Spades) and starting values from 2 to 10.

a_7.informal problem: Find the probability of drawing a combination of one card from each of the four suits and twelve ranks from a standard 52-card deck, without replacement. The final answer is $\frac{12}{5525}$.

shows  "p = (card {S. \<exists> s1 s2 s3. S = {s1, s2, s3} \<and> three_consecutive_same_suit s1 s2 s3}) / (card (subsets_of_size 3 (standard_deck)))"

fixes p :: real

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: In a standard deck of 52 playing cards, find the probability that a randomly chosen set of 3 cards contains three consecutive cards of the same suit. The final answer is $\frac{12}{5525}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob :: real
assumes h0 : "prob = 12 / 5525"
shows  "prob = (card {((a, b), (c, d), (e, f)) | a b c d e f. a \<in> {1..13} \<and> b \<in> {1..4} \<and> c \<in> {1..13} \<and> d \<in> {1..4} \<and> e \<in> {1..13} \<and> f \<in> {1..4} \<and> ((a = c - 1 \<and> c = e - 1) \<or> (a = c + 1 \<and> c = e + 1)) \<and> b = d \<and> d = f}) / (card {(a, b, c) | a b c. a \<in> {1..52} \<and> b \<in> {1..52} \<and> c \<in> {1..52} \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> a \<noteq> c})"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 3 cards are chosen at random from a standard 52-card deck.  What is the probability that they can be arranged into a group of three consecutive cards, all of the same suit? For this problem, an Ace can either come before a 2 or after a King, but not both (so A23 and QKA both count, but KA2 doesn't). The final Answer is \frac{12}{5,\!525}
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{52}{3} = 22,\!100$ ways to choose 3 cards out of 52, without regard to order. For any suit, there are 12 possible triples of consecutive cards (since the three consecutive cards can start on an A, 2, 3, ..., or Q, but not on a K).
 Since there are 4 suits, there are $4\cdot12=48$ valid triples. The chance that three cards chosen randomly are three consecutive cards of the same suit is therefore $\frac{48}{22,\!100}=\boxed{\frac{12}{5,\!525}}$
 *)

theorem
fixes prob :: real
assumes h0 : "prob = 12 / 5525"
shows  "prob = (card {((a, b), (c, d), (e, f)) | a b c d e f. a \<in> {1..13} \<and> b \<in> {1..4} \<and> c \<in> {1..13} \<and> d \<in> {1..4} \<and> e \<in> {1..13} \<and> f \<in> {1..4} \<and> ((a = c - 1 \<and> c = e - 1) \<or> (a = c + 1 \<and> c = e + 1)) \<and> b = d \<and> d = f}) / (card {(a, b, c) | a b c. a \<in> {1..52} \<and> b \<in> {1..52} \<and> c \<in> {1..52} \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> a \<noteq> c})"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In a standard deck of 52 cards, what is the probability of drawing three cards with consecutive numbers (e.g., 4, 5, 6) and with the same suit (e.g., all hearts)? Express your answer as a fraction. The final answer is $\frac{12}{5525}$.
